docs.title: Discord for VT Clubs
docs.text:
Are you a part of student club leadership at Virginia Tech? Looking for a messaging platform that works for clubs big and small? Discord offers means of both mass and personal communication: channels to separate conversations based on topics, roles to separate your officers from regular members, and multiple ways to share your server with new members.

Welcome to the "Discord for VT Clubs" user guide. This guide will outline how to use Discord for your VT club from creating an account to setting up special roles for your club officers.

Discord offers a large variety of features, not all of which will be covered in this guide. This guide takes a streamlined approach, cutting out all of the unnecessary noise of current discord documentation. Instead, it focuses only on the essentials of club communication.

[!Note] Although you can use the mobile app to set up your server, this guide focuses on how to setup a server using the desktop application.

docs.title: Channels
docs.text: Common Channels for Clubs * Channels based on interests * ex: art, design * Channels based on roles * ex: programmer, writer

docs.title: How to add a channel
docs.text:
This section describes how to add a channel. If you need reference on what a channel is, or the different types of channels (ie. Voice vs. Text) see the Discord Anatomy section of this document.

  1. Locate the section you want to add a channel to (ex: Information, Text Channels)
  2. Click the + icon next to the section name
  3. Select the type of channel you want to add ('Text' should be selected automatically, but you can also choose to add a Voice channels or a Forum instead by clicking on the circle to the left of these options)
  4. Type the desired name for your channel next to the # under 'Channel Name' (Optional) if you wish this to be a private channel (ie. for club officers only) toggle the button next to 'Private Channel' at the bottom of the page.
  5. Press Create Channel

docs.title: Renaming Channels
docs.text:
1. Right click on the channel name that you wish to rename
  2. Click Edit Channel
  3. Delete the current name of your channel from the Channel Name text box
  4. Type the desired name for your channel in this same box
  5. Press Save Changes

docs.title: Removing Channels
docs.text:
1. Right click on the channel you wish to delete
  2. Click Delete Channel
  3. Confirm you want to delete the channel by pressing Delete Channel on the new box that pops up

docs.title: Creating a server
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Discord
  2. Select Create a server
  3. Select Club or Community (this allows for very large groups as your club grows)
  4. Add your public name and picture (such as a club logo!)
  5. Create your server!

docs.title: Discord Anatomy
docs.text: This section defines various Discord terms that will be referred to throughout this document. Below are images breaking down your view of Discord on PC.

docs.title: Chat/Direct Message
docs.text:
A way to communicate with members 1:1 or in a small group. Chats are generally more private (you're not sending messages to potentially hundreds of people). Displayed below is a chat to a single user:

You can access direct messages by clicking on the button with the discord logo in the upper-left corner of the screen.

docs.title: Profile
docs.text: This is your Discord account. You use it to join servers and DM others. Your profile is also customizable. Find more information on customizing a profile on this Discord page.

docs.title: Server
docs.text:
The subject of this guide! Made of multiple channels. Much more feature-rich than text chats. May have moderators, roles, and apps. You can find a list of their icons on the left side of your screen.

Below is an image of the server itself and a breakdown of the main features.

docs.title: Channel
docs.text:
Similar to a chat, but exists inside a server so that you, and all of your members, can communicate with each other. There are 2 types of channels that are most commonly used in club servers on Discord: Voice and Text.

  • Voice : Allows you to connect with other members by having live voice (and video) conversations with up to 99 members. Voice channels don't require you to start a call, you just click on the channel to join it. Additionally, members can choose to have their microphone and camera enabled or disabled for privacy.

  • Text : Allows you to connect with other members by texting them. Text channels are like group chats, but you can specifically mention people by using the @ key, followed by the person's username.

    You can also create different channels on Discord (more on this later...) to keep conversations more organized or only allow certain members, such as club leaders, to send messages in a channel.

docs.title: Roles
docs.text:
A way to organize members and grant permissions. Discord's system for roles uses colors (ex: red = the lowest group, purple = administrator, etc). Users with multiple roles will only display the color of their highest role. You can also manage roles (this will be discussed later on in the document).

[!Note] The administrator role has the highest number of permissions. Make sure you assign this role appropriately!

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This section will show you how to download Discord and create an account. Discord can be used on the website, but it is recommended that you use the app to have access to more features.

docs.title: On PC
docs.text: To create an account using your desktop, go to the Discord website and scroll down to where it says Download for [name of your operating system] (i.e "Download for Windows"). Follow the download directions.

docs.title: On Mobile
docs.text: To create an account using your phone, go to the App Store or Google Play and search for "Discord". Hit the download button. Once downloaded, hit the Open button, this will open the app on your phone.

docs.title: Creating an Account
docs.text:
If you are not logged in already, you will need to log in or create an account. To start this, click the Register button. You'll be prompted to enter an email, display name, username, password, and birth date.

An email will be sent to the account you used for registration. Click the Claim Account button. This will claim your account. After claiming your account, a 5 digit number will appear after your username. This is a unique number used to differentiate your account from others.

docs.title: Virginia Tech
docs.text: Any club communication is an extension of the club. Even online, your club leadership and members are subject to the Virginia Tech Principles of Community as well as the Virginia Tech Honor Code. It's important to make students aware of this, for example with a message in a dedicated #rules channel. The tone of the club might be casual, but it's a bad idea to risk your server becoming known as a den of--gasp!--academic dishonestly. If it's easy to join your server, your club members should be reminded that it's easy for people to join the club and read what they're saying.

docs.title: Discord
docs.text: Your club will also be subject to the Discord Terms of Service. Familiarize your club officers with these, here are the most important restrictions: * Don’t use the services to do harm to yourself or others. * Don’t use the services to do harm to Discord. * Don’t use the services to do anything else that’s illegal.

docs.title: Your VT CLub
docs.text: Before using Discord for club communication, talk over the rules and regulations of Discord, the university, and your club. Decide on boundaries, disciplinary actions, and who is responsible for executing these. If club leadership decides that a member should no longer be in the Discord server, see this Discord guide on how to remove members from a server.

docs.title: App directory
docs.text: Discord is itself an "Application" or "App" on your device. Additionally, Discord offers an app directory, with a variety of games and features. These are detailed in this Guide to Discord Apps.

docs.title: Threads
docs.text: Threads allow users to continue conversations on a particular topic without getting mixed around in a big chat. This is particularly useful for scheduling meetings or arranging carpools. Here's a useful guide to threads.

docs.title: Nitro & Server Boosting
docs.text: Nitro is Discord's subscription service. A $10/month subscription grants two server boosts, which can be used on your club server to gain various benefits! These include higher-quality streams making online movie nights more feasible and custom emojis to build club identity. You can consult this FAQ for more information on boosts.

docs.title: More Permissions
docs.text: Discord contains a multitude of permissions for every purpose. This document covers the most pertinent permissions to club leaders. However, if you wish to learn more about permissions refer to Permissions on Discord.

docs.title: Roles and Permissions
docs.text: Your members will have different club roles such as: * Club Officer * Special Roles * ex: writer vs actor for a film * Member Status * ex: active/unactive member or members with paid/unpaid dues

docs.title: How to Make Roles
docs.text:
1. Press the server name in the upper-left corner.
  2. Select Server Settings
  3. Navigate to the Roles tab and select Create Role.
  4. Under Role Name, write an appropriate name for this role. This will be displayed to all discord users. (Optional) Under Role Color select a color for this role. Users's names that have this particular role will be displayed in this color.
  5. Save changes to confirm your selection.

docs.title: Server Permissions
docs.text:
Discord follows a top-down structure for permissions. This means that members can only affect users with roles lower than their highest role. Base permissions are already given to all members automatically, but this doesn't account for role specific permissions. The following section will describe the most useful permission types to give to club officers, or other higher up roles, and then break down how to apply them.

I. Administrator Permission Administrator is the most powerful role as it grants all permissions to the assigned role. This permission should be used with caution. This position is recommended for the club leader, or the club officer responsible for running the discord.

II. Manage Roles Users with this permission can create and modify roles positioned below their own. They cannot assign any permissions to individuals at their own level or higher, nor assign any permissions that they themselves have not been granted. This role is recommended for club officers.

III. Manage Messages The role with this permission can delete messages sent by other members or pin any message. This permission is recommended for club officers, or other members responsible for moderating the server.

IV. Manage Expressions Users with this permission may edit or remove custom emoji, stickers and sounds in this server. This permission is recommended for club officers, or other members responsible for moderating the server.

V. Kick, Approve, and Reject Members Users with this permission can kick other members from this server. Kicked members may rejoin the server if they have another invite. If the server enables Member Requirements, this role can also approve or reject members from joining the server.

VI. Ban Members Allows the role with this permission to permanently ban other members and delete their message history.

Other Permissions There are many more discord permissions built into the application. If you have a specific permission you wish to grant, consult the Permissions on Discord webpage.

docs.title: Assigning Permissions
docs.text:
1. Right click on the server name.
  2. Scroll down to the Server Settings option and hover over it.
  3. Scroll over and down to the Roles option in the new bar next to Server Settings.
  4. Locate the role you want to administer permissions for and select the edit icon located to the right of this role's name.
  5. Click the permissions tab (located at the top of the edit role menu)
  6. Scroll through this menu and find the desired permission >[!Note] >If you are having trouble locating your desired permission, you can also type the name of said permission into the search bar at the top of the screen to locate it faster
  7. Toggle the button to the right of this permission and it should turn green to signal that it has been enabled
  8. Press Save Changes to confirm your selection

docs.title: Sharing the Server
docs.text: Now that you have a working server, you'll want to get your club members in! There are two methods to get club members in your server: invite links, and QR codes.

docs.title: Evergreen Invite Link
docs.text:
This is where we will teach you how to create a permanent invite link to easily share your server with others.

  1. Click on the name of your discord server. You should see these list of options:
  2. Click on the Invite People option. If you have been using Discord before, you'll see a list of friends on Discord as well as any group chats you're in. Invite People is the 2nd option in the dropdown
  3. There will also be a "Or, send a server invite link to a friend". It looks like this:
  4. Click the copy button to copy the invite link. You can now paste the link and send it off.

docs.title: QR Code
docs.text:
1. Copy your invite link
  2. Paste it in the Your url field of QR Code Monkey.
  3. Click Create QR Code
  4. Click Download PNG

docs.title: Evergreen Invite Link
docs.text:
1. Start by clicking the people button

  2. Click copy link(should be the 2nd button)

  3. Paste the link by holding your finger down, and select "Paste" (on iPhone, it should be the first option you see)

docs.title: QR Code
docs.text:
1. Start by clicking the people button

  2. Click on the QR Code button. It's the third button from the left.

  3. You should now see an actual QR Code on your screen. Show this to invitees or screenshot and print!

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Our guide is streamlined and doesn't include everything. If you run into any technical problems, refer to Discord's support site.
